ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned more about some traditions I was not as familiar with: Utilitarianism, Buddhism, Islam, Expressive Individualism, and Nietzsche. I also learned through the essays how to succinctly and clearly describe different visions of life worth living  (Yale's vision, my peer's vision, and my vision). Finally, I learned how to discuss these philosophical topics with my classmates.

By exploring so many different traditions, practices, and religions, I was able to practice engaging with material/ideologies that were completely foreign to me. I feel like I'm much better at thinking deeply, developing questions, and forming opinions about a practice/approach to life that may be very different than mine, as well as using it as a starting point for reflecting on my own beliefs/traditions. Every unit was so fascinating and eye-opening!!

I view myself and my life differently.  I am so grateful for my life and who I have become in college -- but am even more excited to see who I continue to grow into!  It's very cool to think about what I value in life and what makes my life worth living. Definitely got a little existential at times, too.
Learned different perspectives on a life worth living through the lens of philosophical/religious traditions
This is one my favorite courses ever at Yale. Its amazing and really makes you evaluate your life.
learned about different traditions and discussed with classmates

This course really makes you think deeply about the things you value and prioritize in life; you gain a lot of insight from the many traditions practiced in the world and learn how to extract meanings and lessons from these traditions without necessarily diving too much into the history and complexities of them.
Lots of reflection; learning from but not necessarily about religions; main insights gained from classmate commentary/insight into their lives

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Overall, I liked the different traditions chosen for the class, and that there was a mixture of religious and secular ideas. I liked the lectures by the experts as well. The readings were not overwhelming, and as a result I actually managed to read all of them. I really liked my section leader Deborah, and I liked that the class was a low-stakes environment where we were free to explore the ideas of these traditions without fear of judgment. In my section, we also had a Zoom retreat and check-ins at the beginning of each class to discuss what was going on in our lives. It was nice to get to know my section as people and understand how their personal backgrounds contributed to their beliefs.

Weaknesses: It's just hard to examine each tradition in-depth when we are going through so many! (This can't really be changed). I would personally prefer to read more about how the actual traditions are lived, because this can differ from what holy texts describe. Some of the primary source readings (mostly for Judaism, Christianity, and Buddhism) were sort of dense and did not give me a clear picture of how people actually practice those traditions today.

There are too many strengths to list, honestly. This class was one of the most comfortable academic spaces I've been in, had incredible vibes, I learned so much, grew so much, and could feel/see the impact it had on my life and my thinking. However, I do think the beauty of this experience was a result of having a really strong class and instructor! Everyone was always engaged, open minded, friendly, and Deborah did an incredible job facilitating discussions and teaching us.

strengths - very welcoming environment.  The class discussions felt extremely comfortable and vulnerable -- I knew I could be honest and open in these seminars. 

Weaknesses - none...Being over zoom wasn't ideal so I'm excited for other students to get to take this in person!
LOVED the readings, guest lectures, welcoming/supportive nature of the course

DEBORAH IS AMAZING!!!!! My whole
class got to bond a ton and it was a very rewarding experience, even on Zoom.
This class would have been better if it was in person .

Strengths: the discussion format really allowed for us to taking meaningful lessons away from the readings. The biggest strength is the discussions you are able to have with your classmates. The environment of the class was super open and welcoming and allowed you to be vulnerable and honest, though this may vary from section to section. The papers also allowed for a lot of flexibility in my opinion and pertained to topics that affect our daily lives.

Strengths: diverse array of information; open and welcoming class environment 

Weaknesses: learning about religions out of context and without the full picture led to confusion and incomplete understanding

I loved the scope of content, and the discussion format. I think this course could be improved by having at least one reading be a clear (textbook-esque) background of the tradition being discussed. Some of the primary sources were difficult to understand without enough context about the tradition first!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Our class was successfully adapted to Zoom. We had discussions as a full section and smaller discussions in Zoom breakout rooms, both of which were useful. The asynchronous lectures by experts were also interesting, and it was easy to watch them on Canvas.

I was pleasantly surprised by how this course worked virtually. It would have been much more ideal in person but the class and instructor made great efforts to make space still feel comfortable and engaging over zoom. No improvements that I can think of.
Breakout rooms were great. I think the asynchronous portion with Q&A also worked well

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! This class is a great way to get an overview of the world's most common belief systems. It's also a great chance to practice discussing philosophical/religious ideas with classmates without fear. This class probably won't entirely change the way you view the world, but it does force you to actually examine and articulate what you think, which is great.
Yes!
I would HIGHLY recommend this class to literally anyone else. This was the best class I took at Yale.

Yes!!!!  Have already recommended it to everyone I know.  It has been life-changing!  It is challenging but so rewarding; it causes you to look at yourself and your life through such an interesting lens. 

 If you can take it, TAKE IT!!!!
YES! This truly changed my perspective on life. Workload isn't too bad but payoff is great. Deborah was amazing.
ABSOLUTELY. It is a must-take class at Yale. You will not regret it at all!
sure

Yes! This was a fantastic course and I am so grateful for the opportunity to have taken it; I recommend taking it in person if possible simply because I think the conversations we had and our retreat would just be better to experience in person. Overall, the workload is not bad, the readings are super interesting and I genuinely felt that my discussion leader cared about me and my classmates.
Yes!! Great senior year class and provided space to reflect and get to know people!
Yes. The most impactful and useful class i've taken at Yale. Teaches you how to know what is important in life.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The class was primarily a virtual seminar that met twice a week. Most weeks we also watched an asynchronous lecture by an expert in that week's tradition. Then we would submit questions for the expert based on their lecture and they would answer some of the questions in another short video.
virtual seminar, recorded guest lectures, and recorded guest Q&A (fielding student questions)
Virtual section/seminar twice a week, additional recorded lectures sometimes, virtual "retreats".
NA
